div.p: Yours of the 20th recd Saturday. I am glad that Charlie is willing to go back to Shayer it is the best I can do for her at present and she learns with such ease it would be a pity if she should not Graduate afterward she can direct her attention most particularly to any branch she may fancyn be deficient it I hope Harriet is better I am uneasy about her. and would like to consult Dr. Pulte if I could. I hope she may be able to attend to her studies. Poor Annie I hope will be better than me now and get some flesh on her bones. I hope you got your money safe and before you run out. Mr Thompson

the Express receipt for the Storebillwhich I hope also came safe to him You cannot wait to see me more than I do you. but this place is so exciting that I had rather forego the pleasure of your company then have you here - whenever the Rebels get away from the vicinity I will write for you to come. I wish I could be with you all but do not see how I can support you in any other manner than by what I now get - I should write H Tallcottin a few days and thank him for thinking of me and speaking to Dr. Gurnne but I am rather too old to go to digging Gold. I wish I had a sufficiency of it or even of Green backs to buy a house S c_but am truly thankful for what I do got I could not write yesterday the servant not having cleaned out the office and madefire. I have not
as yet got me appointment but expect it daily. Kiss the children for me
Mrs Wm. R Hackley Bloomington, Ills
